sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates a simple message flow which retrieves existing Account records from a Salesforce system using the SalesforceRequest node. The flow exposes a HTTP service which accepts some filter properties to limit the number of Account records returned. The records are returned as an array of JSON objects.

The SalesforceRequest node in IBM App Connect Enterprise allows message flows to be developed that can Create, Retrieve, Update and Delete records for the different objects that exist in a Salesforce system, such as Account, Contact and Lead. Records may be retrieved by Salesforce ID, by custom external ID, or by SOQL WHERE clause. Records may be updated by Salesforce ID or by custom external ID. Records may be deleted by Salesforce ID.
The SalesforceRequest node uses the Force.com REST API to exchange data with Salesforce, and so the input and output message trees for the SalesforceRequest node are in the JSON domain.

Each Salesforce object is described by a JSON schema, which may be used as the input or output schema for a Mapping node. The JSON schema for Salesforce objects are provided in the server/sample/Salesforce folder of your IBM Integration Bus installation, and must be copied into a shared library or REST API project. The map using the JSON schema must reside in the same container as the schema.
You will import an application and a shared library into your Toolkit workspace, configure the connection to the Salesforce system, and invoke the message flow using the Flow Exerciser.

sections.section: The Salesforce_Retrieve application and Salesforce_Schemas shared library are now shown in the Application Development view of your workspace.
Click on the Salesforce Request node in the message flow. In the Properties view, the Operation is Retrieve and the Salesforce object is Account.
Change the Salesforce URL property to the URL of a Salesforce system to which you have access.

In order for the SalesforceRequest node to communicate with Salesforce, a Connected App must be created in the Salesforce system and a Security Identity must be created in IBM App Connect Enterprise using mqsisetdbparms. Follow the Configuring a secure connection to Salesforce.com link in the Find out more section to perform these tasks. The Security Identity should be called sf1 to match the Salesforce Request node property, or you can create one with your own name and update the node property.
If you are using a standalone integration server (where C:\MyServer is the server's work directory) then the command will look similar to this:
mqsisetdbparms -w C:\MyServer -n salesforce::sf1 -u myUserID -p myPassword -c myClientIdentity -s myClientSecret
If you are using a node-owned integration server (where TESTNODE is the name of the integration node) then the command will look similar to this:
mqsisetdbparms TESTNODE -n salesforce::sf1 -u myUserID -p myPassword -c myClientIdentity -s myClientSecret
Restart your integration node (or server) for the mqsisetdbparms command to take effect.
Next you will use the Flow exerciser to send HTTP requests to the message flow.

sections.section: Having set-up the required security identity, we will now deploy and test the scenario:

details.details: Drag and drop deploy the shared libarary named Salesforce_Schemas on to your integration server.
Open the Salesforce_Retrieve message flow and click the Flow Exerciser icon to deploy the flow and start recording.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.

Choose Input.json. The JSON message data contains two filter parameters, Limit and Skip. These will be set in the LocalEnvironment section used for the SalesforceRequest node, and control the number of records that are returned. Change the values if you want more than 10 records, or if you want to skip records.
Click Send. Your message is sent to the HTTP Input node.
In the Progress Information dialog, click on Received HTTP reply message ... to view the output message from the flow. The Account records have been returned as a JSON array.

sections.section: After you close the dialog, the message path is automatically highlighted on the message flow. Click on any connection to see the data that passed through that connection. You can see that:

details.details: The Prepare Filter Map node set the Limit and Skip values in the LocalEnvironment section used for the SalesforceRequest node.
The Salesforce Request node retrieved up to the number of Account records specified by Limit and Skip, and propagated them as a JSON array.
The Select Fields Map node removed unwanted fields from each record in the array, using a map built from the JSON schema for the Account object.

sections.section: Repeat the steps above, but this time choose message InputWithWhere.json. The JSON message data additionally contains a where filter parameter, which is a Salesforce Object Query Language (SOQL) expression. This is also set in the LocalEnvironment, and further limits the returned records to those Accounts created since 1st January 2015. Change the value if you want to use an alternative SOQL expression.

If the Flow Exerciser failed to deploy the projects, or the flow failed to retrieve the records from the Salesforce system, follow the Resolving problems when you use Salesforce nodes link in the Find out more section to diagnose the problem.
